case_name: Assistant Registrar of Companies, West Bengal v. officers directors of the Standard Paint Works P Ltd.

facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 248 to 251 of 1968 were heard by the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeals Nos. 248 to 251 of 1968. Appeals from the judgment an order dated August 13, 1968 of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 425 to 428 of 1968.

facts.text: Appeals arose from judgment and order dated August 13, 1968 of Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 425 to 428 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment an order dated August 13, 1968 of the Calcutta High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 425 to 428 of 1968. M. Singhvi and S. P. Nayar, for the appepant  in all the appears . The respondent did number appear.

facts.text: Calcutta High Court held that memorandums of appeals from orders of acquittal were barred by Article 114 of the Limitation Act, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: judgment dated 13 August, 1968 of the High Court at Calcutta holding that 8 60 the memorandum of appeals from an order of, acquittal were barred by Article 114 of the Limitation Act, 1963. The appeals were directed against orders of acquittal passed by the Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta on 4 April, 1968.

facts.text: Orders of acquittal passed by Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta on 4 April 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals were directed against orders of acquittal passed by the Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta on 4 April, 1968. The four petitions of appeal were presented in the High Court on 1 July, 1968 by the learned Advocate authorised by the, Vakalatnama executed by the Assistant Registrar of Companies, West Bengal described as the appellant in all the petitions.

facts.text: Four petitions of appeal presented in Calcutta High Court on 1 July 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The four petitions of appeal were presented in the High Court on 1 July, 1968 by the learned Advocate authorised by the, Vakalatnama executed by the Assistant Registrar of Companies, West Bengal described as the appellant in all the petitions. The Assistant Registrar of Companies, West Bengal filed petitions of companyplaint before the Chief. Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta alleging that the certain officers directors of the Standard Paint Works  P  Ltd.

facts.text: Petitions of appeal presented by learned Advocate authorised by Vakalatnama executed by Assistant Registrar of Companies, West Bengal.

anchor.surface_text: by the learned Advocate authorised by the, Vakalatnama executed by the Assistant Registrar of Companies, West Bengal described as the appellant in all the petitions. The Assistant Registrar of Companies, West Bengal filed petitions of companyplaint before the Chief. Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta alleging that the certain officers directors of the Standard Paint Works  P  Ltd. of 44 Beadon Row, Calcutta mentioned therein were guilty of offence for number-compliance with provisions companytained in the Companies Act, 1956 by reason of default in filing Annual Return of the Company together with the Annual Accounts and Balance sheet.

facts.text: Assistant Registrar of Companies, West Bengal filed complaints before Chief Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta.

anchor.surface_text: The Assistant Registrar of Companies, West Bengal filed petitions of companyplaint before the Chief. Presidency Magistrate, Calcutta alleging that the certain officers directors of the Standard Paint Works  P  Ltd. of 44 Beadon Row, Calcutta mentioned therein were guilty of offence for number-compliance with provisions companytained in the Companies Act, 1956 by reason of default in filing Annual Return of the Company together with the Annual Accounts and Balance sheet. Section 210 of the Companies Act requires annual accounts and balance, sheet of the companypany to be filed within the time mentioned in the section.

facts.text: Officers and directors of Standard Paint Works P Ltd., 44 Beadon Row, Calcutta, alleged guilty of non-compliance with Companies Act 1956 by default in filing Annual Return, Annual Accounts and Balance Sheet.

anchor.surface_text: alleging that the certain officers directors of the Standard Paint Works  P  Ltd. of 44 Beadon Row, Calcutta mentioned therein were guilty of offence for number-compliance with provisions companytained in the Companies Act, 1956 by reason of default in filing Annual Return of the Company together with the Annual Accounts and Balance sheet. Section 210 of the Companies Act requires annual accounts and balance, sheet of the companypany to be filed within the time mentioned in the section. If any person being a director of the companypany fails to take all reasonable steps to companyply with the provisions of section 210, he shall, in respect of each offence. be punishable with imprisonment for a term which may extend to six months, or with fine which may extend to one thousand rupees, or with both.

facts.text: Complainant prayed for exemption of personal appearance under proviso to section 247 CrPC read with section 621A Companies Act.

anchor.surface_text: The companyplainant in filing the petitions of companyplaint prayed for exemption of personal appearance under proviso to section 247 of the Code of Criminal Procedure read with section 621 1 A of the Companies Act. The Presidency Magistrate passed the orders of acquittal in all the cases. Section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure speaks of appeal in case of acquittal.

facts.text: Presidency Magistrate passed orders of acquittal in all cases.

anchor.surface_text: The Presidency Magistrate passed the orders of acquittal in all the cases. Section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure speaks of appeal in case of acquittal. Sub-section  3  of thatsection is as follows If such an order of acquittal is passed in any case instituted upon companyplaint and the. High Court, on an. application made to it by the companyplainant. in this behalf, grants special leave to appeal from the order of acquittal, the companyplainant may present such an appeal to the High Court.

facts.text: No application made to High Court under section 417(3) CrPC for special leave to appeal.

anchor.surface_text: No 8 application was made to the High Court in companynpiance with section 417  3  of the Code of Criminal Procedure. On behalf of the appellant it was companytended both in the High, Court and in this Court that the appeals were preferred under section 624B of the Companies Act, 1956.

facts.text: Appellant contended that appeals were preferred under section 624B of Companies Act 1956.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant it was companytended both in the High, Court and in this Court that the appeals were preferred under section 624B of the Companies Act, 1956. Section 624B is as follows Notwithstanding anything companytained in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898, the Central Government may, in any case arising out of this Act, direct any companypany prosecutor or authorise any other person either by name or by virtue of his office, to present an appeal from an order of acquittal passed by any Court other than a High Court and an appeal presented by such prosecutor or other person shall be deemed to have been validly presented to the appellate Court

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected contention that right of appeal conferred by section 624B Companies Act.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention on behalf of the appellant that the right of appeal is companyferred by section 624B of the Companies Act is unacceptable. Section 624B only speaks of the Central Government directing or authorising any person to present an appeal from the order of acquittal. Section 417 1  of the Code of Criminal Procedure enacts that in case of acquittal the State Government may direct the Public Prosecutor to present an appeal to the High Court.

facts.text: Petitions of appeal presented on 1 July 1968, more than 60 days after acquittal on 4 April 1968.

anchor.surface_text: The orders of acquittal were passed on 4 April, 1968. The petitions of appeal were presented on 1 July, 1968. The appeals were rightly number entertained by the High Court because first there was numberapplication for grant of special leave-under section 417 3  of the Code of Criminal Procedure secondly, the appeals were incompetent without grant of special leave, and thirdly these were barred by limitation.

facts.text: High Court did not entertain appeals due to no special leave application, incompetence, and barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals were rightly number entertained by the High Court because first there was numberapplication for grant of special leave-under section 417 3  of the Code of Criminal Procedure secondly, the appeals were incompetent without grant of special leave, and thirdly these were barred by limitation. An appeal under section 417  3  against acquittal is companypetent only when there is special leave granted by the High Court.
The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed.
M. Singhvi and S. P. Nayar, for the appepant  in all the appears . The respondent did number appear. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Ray, J.

anchor.surface_text: Section 624B of the Companies Act empowers the Central Government to present appeals through persons mentioned in that section. Presentation of appeal by the Central Government is a similar provision to section 417 1  of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Chapter XXXI of the Code of Criminal Procedure relates to, appeals.

Chapter XXXI of the Code of Criminal Procedure relates to, appeals. Appeal is a creature of statute. The right to appeal is governed by the Code of Criminal Procedure.-, Section 404 of the Code of Criminal Procedure states that numberappeal shall lie from any judgment or order of a Criminal Court except as provided for by the Code of Criminal Procedure or by any other law for the time being in force.

anchor.surface_text: The right to appeal to the High Court in the present cases of acquittal is governed by section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Article 114 of the Limitation Act, 1963 requires appeal under sub-section  3  of section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to be filed within 30 days from the date of the grant of special leave.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal under section 417 3  against acquittal is companypetent only when there is special leave granted by the High Court. On obtaining special leave the appeal is thereafter filed within 30 days of the grant of leave to escape the mischief of the period of limitation under Article 114 ,.of the Limitation Act, 1963. A provision in the Companies Act which companyfers right of appeal is section 483. It speaks of appeals from orders made and the decisions given in the matter of winding up of the companypanies by the Court and it enacts that such appeals shall lie to the same Court to which, in the same manner in which, and subject to the same ,conditions under which, appeals lie from any order or decision of the Court in cases within its ordinary jurisdiction.

concepts.interpretation: Confers right of appeal in winding up matters, unlike S624B

anchor.surface_text: Section 624B of the Companies Act empowers the Central Government to present appeals through persons mentioned in that section. Presentation of appeal by the Central Government is a similar provision to section 417(1) of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

anchor.surface_text: Chapter XXXI of the Code of Criminal Procedure relates to, appeals. Appeal is a creature of statute. The right to appeal is governed by the Code of Criminal Procedure.-, Section 404 of the Code of Criminal Procedure states that no appeal shall lie from any judgment or order of a Criminal Court except as provided for by the Code of Criminal Procedure or by any other law for the time being in force.

arguments.claim: Section 624B of the Companies Act does not confer any right of appeal from any order passed by a Criminal Court in respect of any offence under the provisions of the Companies Act

anchor.surface_text: Section 404 of the Code of Criminal Procedure states that no appeal shall lie from any judgment or order of a Criminal Court except as provided for by the Code of Criminal Procedure or by any other law for the time being in force. Section 624B of the Companies Act does not confer any right of appeal from any order passed by a Criminal Court in respect of any offence under the provisions of the Companies Act.

arguments.claim: The right to appeal to the High Court in the present cases of acquittal is governed by section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Article 114 of the Limitation Act, 1963 requires appeal under sub-section (3) of section 417 to be filed within 30 days from the date of the grant of special leave

anchor.surface_text: The right to appeal to the High Court in the present cases of acquittal is governed by section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Article 114 of the Limitation Act, 1963 requires appeal under sub-section (3) of section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to be filed within 30 days from the date of the grant of special leave.

arguments.claim: The appeals were rightly not entertained by the High Court because first there was no application for grant of special leave under section 417(3) of the Code of Criminal Procedure secondly, the appeals were incompetent without grant of special leave, and thirdly these were barred by limitation

anchor.surface_text: The orders of acquittal were passed on 4 April, 1968. The petitions of appeal were presented on 1 July, 1968. The appeals were rightly not entertained by the High Court because first there was no application for grant of special leave-under section 417(3) of the Code of Criminal Procedure secondly, the appeals were incompetent without grant of special leave, and thirdly these were barred by limitation.

arguments.claim: An appeal under section 417(3) against acquittal is competent only when there is special leave granted by the High Court

anchor.surface_text: The appeals were rightly not entertained by the High Court because first there was no application for grant of special leave-under section 417(3) of the Code of Criminal Procedure secondly, the appeals were incompetent without grant of special leave, and thirdly these were barred by limitation. An appeal under section 417(3) against acquittal is competent only when there is special leave granted by the High Court.

arguments.claim: Section 483 [of Companies Act] confers right of appeal [unlike S624B]

anchor.surface_text: An appeal under section 417(3) against acquittal is competent only when there is special leave granted by the High Court. On obtaining special leave the appeal is thereafter filed within 30 days of the grant of leave to escape the mischief of the period of limitation under Article 114 of the Limitation Act, 1963. A provision in the Companies Act which confers right of appeal is section 483.

holdings.text: The contention on behalf of the appellant that the right of appeal is conferred by section 624B of the Companies Act is unacceptable. Section 624B only speaks of the Central Government directing or authorising any person to present an appeal from the order of acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention on behalf of the appellant that the right of appeal is companyferred by section 624B of the Companies Act is unacceptable. Section 624B only speaks of the Central Government directing or authorising any person to present an appeal from the order of acquittal. Section 417 1  of the Code

holdings.reasoning_summary: Section 624B authorizes presentation but does not create substantive right of appeal, analogous to CrPC S.417(1).

holdings.text: Appeal is a creature of statute. The right to appeal is governed by the Code of Criminal Procedure. Section 404 of the Code of Criminal Procedure states that no appeal shall lie from any judgment or order of a Criminal Court except as provided for by the Code of Criminal Procedure or by any other law for the time being in force.

anchor.surface_text: Chapter XXXI of the Code of Criminal Procedure relates to, appeals. Appeal is a creature of statute. The right to appeal is governed by the Code of Criminal Procedure.-, Section 404 of the Code of Criminal Procedure states that no appeal shall lie from any judgment or order of a Criminal Court except as provided for by the Code of Criminal Procedure or by any other law for the time being in force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Right to appeal exists only as expressly provided by statute, particularly CrPC Chapter XXXI.

holdings.text: Section 624B of the Companies Act does not confer any right of appeal from any order passed by a Criminal Court in respect of any offence under the provisions of the Companies Act.

anchor.surface_text: Section 624B of the Companies Act does not confer any right of appeal from any order passed by a Criminal Court in respect of any offence under the provisions of the Companies Act. The right to appeal to the High Court in the present cases of acquittal is governed by section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.624B addresses who may present appeal but not the existence of the right, per S.404 CrPC.

holdings.text: The right to appeal to the High Court in the present cases of acquittal is governed by section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Article 114 of the Limitation Act, 1963 requires appeal under sub-section 3 of section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to be filed within 30 days from the date of the grant of special leave.

anchor.surface_text: The right to appeal to the High Court in the present cases of acquittal is governed by section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Article 114 of the Limitation Act, 1963 requires appeal under sub-section 3 of section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to be filed within 30 days from the date of the grant of special leave.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Acquittal appeals follow CrPC S.417(3) procedure and Limitation Act Art.114 timeline from special leave grant.

holdings.text: No application for the grant of special leave to appeal from an order of acquittal was made within 60 days from that order of acquittal.

anchor.surface_text: Article 114 of the Limitation Act, 1963 requires appeal under sub-section 3 of section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to be filed within 30 days from the date of the grant of special leave. No application for the grant of special leave to appeal from an order of acquittal was made within 60 days from that order of acquittal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.417(4) CrPC bars entertainment of special leave applications after 60 days from acquittal.

holdings.text: The appeals were rightly not entertained by the High Court because first there was no application for grant of special leave under section 417(3) of the Code of Criminal Procedure, secondly, the appeals were incompetent without grant of special leave, and thirdly these were barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The orders of acquittal were passed on 4 April, 1968. The petitions of appeal were presented on 1 July, 1968. The appeals were rightly not entertained by the High Court because first there was no application for grant of special leave-under section 417 3 of the Code of Criminal Procedure secondly, the appeals were incompetent without grant of special leave, and thirdly these were barred by limitation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of special leave under S.417(3), combined with time bar under S.417(4) and Art.114, renders appeals invalid.

holdings.text: An appeal under section 417(3) against acquittal is competent only when there is special leave granted by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal under section 417 3 against acquittal is competent only when there is special leave granted by the High Court. On obtaining special leave the appeal is thereafter filed within 30 days of the grant of leave to escape the mischief of the period of limitation under Article 114 ,.of the Limitation Act, 1963.

holdings.reasoning_summary: S.417(3) CrPC mandates prior special leave for complainant appeals against acquittal.

holdings.text: Section 624B is not such a section which can be said to be conferring a right of appeal. Section 624B only mentions as to the person through whom appeal is presented.

anchor.surface_text: A provision in the Companies Act which confers right of appeal is section 483. It speaks of appeals from orders made and the decisions given in the matter of winding up of the companypanies by the Court and it enacts that such appeals shall lie to the same Court to which, in the same manner in which, and subject to the same ,conditions under which, appeals lie from any order or decision of the Court in cases within its ordinary jurisdiction. Section 624B is not such a section which can be said to be conferring a right of appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contrasts S.624B with S.483 Companies Act, which explicitly confers appeal rights in winding-up matters.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed.

outcome.relief_summary: The appeals fail and are dismissed as incompetent without special leave under section 417(3) CrPC and barred by limitation under Article 114 of Limitation Act

anchor.surface_text: Chapter XXXI of the Code of Criminal Procedure relates to, appeals. Appeal is a creature of statute. The right to appeal is governed by the Code of Criminal Procedure.-, Section 404 of the Code of Criminal Procedure states that no appeal shall lie from any judgment or order of a Criminal Court except as provided for by the Code of Criminal Procedure or by any other law for the time being in force.
The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Section 624B of the Companies Act does not confer any right of appeal from any order passed by a Criminal Court in respect of any offence under the provisions of the Companies Act. anchor.surface_text: The right to appeal to the High Court in the present cases of acquittal is governed by section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Article 114 of the Limitation Act, 1963 requires appeal under sub-section 3 of section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to be filed within 30 days from the date of the grant of special leave.
The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed.

edges.explanation: Absence of timely special leave application in h5 supports the general holding h7 that appeal is not competent without such leave

anchor.surface_text: Article 114 of the Limitation Act, 1963 requires appeal under sub-section 3 of section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to be filed within 30 days from the date of the grant of special leave. No application for the grant of special leave to appeal from an order of acquittal was made within 60 days from that order of acquittal.
The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed.
he High Court in the present cases of acquittal is governed by section 417 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Article 114 of the Limitation Act, 1963

edges.explanation: Holding h6 notes absence of special leave application under s417(3), explaining why appeals not entertained, addressing limitation issue i1

anchor.surface_text: The orders of acquittal were passed on 4 April, 1968. The petitions of appeal were presented on 1 July, 1968. The appeals were rightly not entertained by the High Court because first there was no application for grant of special leave-under section 417 3 of the Code of Criminal Procedure secondly, the appeals were incompetent without grant of special leave, and thirdly these were barred by limitation.
The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed.

edges.explanation: Holding h7 directly answers issue i3 by affirming appeal competence requires special leave

anchor.surface_text: An appeal under section 417 3 against acquittal is competent only when there is special leave granted by the High Court. On obtaining special leave the appeal is thereafter filed within 30 days of the grant of leave to escape the mischief of the period of limitation under Article 114 ,.of the Limitation Act, 1963.
The appeals therefore fail and are dismissed.
